Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: Stakeholders expect a working prototype soon to secure internal approval
Story: I sat at my cluttered desk, blueprints spread out before me, the hum of my laptop barely masking the voices drifting from the living room. My stepmother’s words echoed in my mind: “This year, you must help us prepare for the festival. It’s important to your father.” I knew what she meant—my presence, my effort, would prove I belonged, that I respected their traditions. But my phone buzzed with another reminder from my project manager: “Prototype demo in two days. Stakeholders need to see progress.” The pressure was mounting. I was supposed to be the reliable engineer, the one who could deliver under tight deadlines. Yet, as the festival approached, my family’s expectations grew louder, their glances sharper. I felt torn, my loyalty stretched thin between the world I was trying to build at work and the one I was still trying to fit into at home. My hands hovered over the keyboard, mind racing, heart heavy, knowing that whatever I chose, something would be left undone.
